title: Reza Hakimazar
text:
I am a master’s student in research psychology at the University of Hamburg, currently working on my master’s thesis about mate-accuracy of face perception.
My academic interests include social psychology 1, and science communication 2. Recently, I have also been focusing on improving my skills in quantitative research methods in psychology & learning about causal inference, modelling and its application in social psychology.

title: The Jotter Pen
text:
Here is called The Jotter Pen because of the famous pen by Parker Pens called The Jotter Pen. This pen is highly popular and has become an icon in the pen industry. On the top is a photo of the real Jotter Pen. I have named here The Jotter Pen because this is a place where I jot(write quickly and briefly)! These blog posts are mostly sketches of my ideas. They may be followed up or just rest here till either I or GitHub die.

title: Reza Hakimazar
text:
Experience

Participant Recrutment and Research Assistant
Hamburg, Germany | March 2025 - ongoing
 To gain deeper insight into the research process and acquire hands-on experience, I manage participant data, recruit participants, and expand my knowledge in computational modelling. This diverse set of tasks not only challenges my flexibility in handling a wide range of responsibilities but also actively involves me in the research process, allowing me to gain practical experience under the guidance of post-doctoral researchers Dr. Alexa Ruel, Dr. Xiangjuan Ren, and Dr. Alexander Nitsch at the Learning & Mechanisms of Change department at the University of Hamburg.


Open Educational Resources Project , Research Assistant
Hamburg, Germany | September 2024 - March 2025
 This project is under the supervision of Dr. Lennart Wittkuhn at the University of Hamburg. The project aims to decentralize educational materials and make them more accessible for professors and students.


Track, Organize and Share your work: An Introduction to Git for Psychological Research , Teaching and Research Assistant
Hamburg, Germany | November 2024 - March 2025
 This course is provided by Dr. Lennart Wittkuhn at Erasmus University Rotterdam and University of Hamburg. The course aims to familiarize the students with applications of Git in psychological research.


Ravanyara Psychology Group , Founder
Isfahan, Iran - Remote from Hamburg | October 2022 - present
 Directed the remote organization of 3 scientific workshops, directly engaging with 100+ attendees and managing all communications - Published two issues of a psychology magazine for the public. - Implemented a feedback loop system to address customer inquiries, resulting in a 25 percent decrease in unresolved issues


Faculty of Psychology, University of Isfahan , Magazine Editor-in-chief
Isfahan, Iran | February 2021 - September 2022
 Collaborated with authors to write simple scientific reviews - Managed team of 10+ student editors and writers - Issued 7 volumes of scientific magazine


Faculty of Psychology, University of Isfahan , Board Member of Psychology Student Association
Isfahan, Iran | November 2018 - February 2021
 Coordinated academic projects, liaising with professors, administration offices,and external entities to facilitate smooth project execution - Helped over 200 students to access better education quality - Organized 10+ education workshops

title: Day 00 - Start the Challenge
text:
This is the official start of my new challenge:

I have recently started to work out, gonna keep it going.
I’m gonna begin with lowering my daily social media consumption.
Replace social media with TV series, movies, and books.
And most importantly, I’m gonna read a research paper every day or every two days.

I’m just documenting these here to throw them out of my mind. I believe this can be the first step of transforming ideas into actions— probably the hardest thing for humans.
The word challenge translates to die Herausforderung, which, as far as I understand, illustrates the idea of something that calls you out and demands a response. I find it interesting and thoughtful.

title: Day 01 - A Disappointing Start
text:
It was not good. I couldn’t reduce my screen time, hit the gym, or read a paper. On the other hand I watched 2 episodes of Succession, what a masterpiece!
Next day will be better.

title: hate-visualizations
text: This document contains a series of visualizations about hate victimization cases in different countries. The data is collected within the framework of our project called Crossing Borders, Confronting Bias – Researching Culturally Competent Care for Minorities and Marginalized Groups Through the Eyes of Early Career Students.

title: hate-visualizations
text: This document contains a series of visualizations about hate victimization cases in different countries. The data is collected within the framework of our project called Crossing Borders, Confronting Bias – Researching Culturally Competent Care for Minorities and Marginalized Groups Through the Eyes of Early Career Students.

title: hate-visualizations
section: Top 3 reported hate crime types in each country
text:
Top 3 reported hate crime types in each country
This plot shows the three highest reported hate crime types in the countries in relatively broad conceptual categories.

title: hate-visualizations
section: Frequency of Hate Crime Categories in the Dataset
text:
Frequency of Hate Crime Categories in the Dataset
This plot is a continuation of the previous one. It shows what types of hate crimes were most frequently reported as the top three categories in the countries. As we can see, racism and xenophobia are the leading category, followed by LGBTQ+ related hate crime and religious hate crime.

title: hate-visualizations
text:
Psychologists needed!
The plot below shows how many psychologists are active per 100k population in each country. India, as expected due to its population, has the lowest ratio of psychologists. Iran is the second to last after Turkey and Germany, which is in urgent need of psychologists. Recently, there have been demands for a reform in the psychology training system of the country.

title: hate-visualizations
text:
Urbanization and psychologists
We can expect that with an increase in the ratio of urbanization, which can be an indicator of development, the number of psychologists will increase as well. As you can see in the data, there is not a strong relationship between the number of psychologists and how urbanized the country is (r = 0.20). The low correlation indicates that there are more important factors feeding into the lack of psychologists in different countries, such as the educational system, cultural values, economic status, etc.

title: hate-visualizations
text:
Hate victimization trend and psychologists
In this plot, we see the overall distribution of psychologists per 100k based on the victimization trend in each country. What we can learn from the plot is that, first of all, unfortunately, the trend is increasing in most of the countries. Second, a low number of psychologists doesn’t always mean an increase in hate victimization. Third, countries that have an increasing trend have more psychologists than other countries in most cases. It reflects the importance of creating groups of experts from different fields to solve this multidimensional problem and not relying only on psychologists. The bad news is that we couldn’t find decreasing trends in the countries we collected data from. This can also be an indicator of better data communication and hate vicimization cases being recognized.

title: hate-visualizations
text:
Data source officiality
A huge challenge for gathering this data was the credibility of the sources. Many countries are not very transparent about the hate crime data. In order to capture the data we wanted, we had to refer to unofficial sources as well and cross-validate them. Here is a plot comparing the unofficial and official source numbers. As illustrated in the plot, most of the data is gathered using both ways.

title: hate-visualizations
section: Hate crimes in the countries with more transparent data
text: Hate crimes in the countries with more transparent data

title: hate-visualizations
text:
Country specific plots
Here, we zoom in a bit to identify more nuanced trends and issues of each country. It should be noted that not all the data allowed us to plot based on country. Only a few countries publish regular, clean, and reliable data regarding hate crime, which is a major obstacle.

title: hate-visualizations
text:
Official vs. unofficial data sources
A huge challenge for gathering this data was the credibility of the sources. Many countries are not very transparent about the hate crime data. In order to capture the data we wanted, we had to refer to unofficial sources as well and cross-validate them. Here is a plot comparing the unofficial and official source numbers. As illustrated in the plot, most of the data is gathered using both ways.

title: LoM-Wacker
text: Universität Hamburg Geschäftsstelle Deutschlandstipendium Rothenbaumchaussee 19 Hamburg 20148 Reza Hakimazar c/o Rajaei Bürgerweide 53 Hamburg 20535 Subject: Letter of Motivation for Deutschlandstipendium Dear Selection Committee, I am writing to express my genuine enthusiasm for the Deutschlandstipendium. My name is Reza Hakimazar, a second-year master’s level student in research psychology at the University of Hamburg. As a top-level student, I consider myself an ideal candidate for this prestigious stipend. I truly believe that my personal achievements, academic accomplishments, and social commitments reflect the ideals of this scholarship. I have a GPA of 1.3 in my current studies, which is in a highly challenging field, even for gaining admission given its NC-restriction, let alone achieving outstanding grades. This strong academic record is not limited to my ongoing studies only, since I completed my bachelor’s degree with a 1.4 total GPA, which placed me among the top 15% of students at graduation, showcasing the longevity and consistency of my efforts. Professionally, I am committed to two projects at the University of Hamburg, namely Digital and Data Literacy in Teaching Lab and Implementing FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) and Reproducible Teaching. In these projects, I focus on crafting a concrete framework to make teaching materials sustainable, first at the University of Hamburg, with the goal of implementing these principles at more universities and research institutes around the world. I contribute to this project by increasing the longevity of the teaching materials, such as lecture slides, research outputs, and guides This can decrease the workload of academics by a sizable amount. They will not need to redo everything to prepare materials for each semester, leading to a more sustainable approach to teaching. In the research area, academia can benefit from the sustainability features of the project by making research computationally reproducible. As a psychology student, I am eager to contribute to resolving the so-called replication crisis in psychology, which is a long-recognized problem in psychological research that results in the failure to replicate 39% of high-impact psychology studies. Beyond academics, I have been and continue to be involved in several community-focused initiatives that help marginalized groups, such as refugees, especially Afghan asylum seekers. This aligns with my research skills gained during writing my bachelor’s thesis on investigating discrimination and its effects among women in Iran. As a part of the international Hate Victimization: Culturally Competent Care for Minorities and Marginalized Groups project organized by the European Federation of Psychology Students’ Associations (EFPSA), I am working on enhancing the quality of life of the refugees in Germany and Iran. I am investigating the occurrence of hate speech, social exclusion, and perceived discrimination among Afghan refugees in Iran and Germany. Through this project, I hope to have an impact on policy makers in both countries to improve the situation of the refugees in the two countries. The results of this research program will be presented at the EFPSA Congress 2025 in Turkey. My dedication to binding psychology and society goes further by establishing a remotely managed non-profit organization called Ravanyaraa Psychology Group in Iran. At Ravanyaraa, we hold workshops, consultyoung students, and publish a psychology magazine for laypeople. I believe that science communication is significant to build trust between public and scientific institutes. I am the editor-in-chief and layout designer of the magazine and also the manager of this organization. I had the idea of creating my own psychology group during my bachelor’s when I was a board member of the Psychology Student Association at the University of Isfahan. This association fosters academic discussion and community learning at the university. I was engaged in these activities throughout all four years of my bachelor’s. Volunteering and public engagement have also been important aspects of my journey. I was part of an Accessibility Improvement Project in Isfahan, the third largest city in Iran, conducting field research and collaborating with public authorities to enhance street accessibility for people with disabilities. Also, I was selected to volunteer in a group to provide psychological first aid for Afghan families in the city of Isfahan, Iran by The United Nation Refugee Agency. Coming from a Middle Eastern developing country, financial hurdles have always been significant obstacles for me. In Iran, there is an undeclared, unoffcial ongoing conflict that has severely impacted my family’s financial status, my primary source of support. Due to this adverse situation, I have encountered visa extension problems, as one of the main documents required for extending a residence permit is proof of a plausible source of income. Therefore, the Deutschlandstipendium would play a critical role in solving this problem and would relieve a lot of tension. Furthermore, this scholarship would help me focus mainly on my study, social, and academic projects. Without the worry of paying bills, I can concentrate on using my psychological knowledge to solve real-world problems in my ongoing projects. I feel deeply connected to the values of the Deutschlandstipendium, and I believe that receiving this award will undoubtedly push me a step closer to making the world a better, more sustainable place. Thank you for considering my application. Sincerely, Reza Hakimazar 2

title: The EEG Lab Protocol
text:
This document is a guide on how to use the EEG lab for a testing session. Depending on your specific study, some steps might be added or modified. Neverthelss, this guide is the basis for a clean and smooth testing procedure. All rules should be respected, unless the primary investigator for your study tells you otherwise.






WARNING



As the EEG equipment is very expensive and some parts of the equipment are also fragile, the entire procedure should be done with great carethis document should be read carefully.


For any questions or in case of unexpected incidents, please reach out to the following people:

Alexa Ruel (alexa.ruel@uni-hamburg.de ; office VMP5, Room 4077)
Marit Petzka (marit.petzka@uni-hamburg.de)
Nicolas Schuck (nicolas.schuck@uni-hamburg.de)

title: Final Cleanup
text:
Step 1: Shut down both computers.
Step 2: Ensure at least 2 clean towels are ready for the next day. If not, do laundry in Room 4135 (will need about 4.5 hours to complete).



Laundry Room


Step 3: Lock all the doors.




Step 1: Put the laundry detergent in the left-hand compartment.
Step 2: Set the washing program on “Koch/Buntwasche”.
Step 3: 60 degrees.
Step 4: Choose quick cycle on the screen.
Step 5: Choose drying cycle to be the wardrobe.










Put the Laundry Detergent







Set the Washing Program









Set the Temparature







Choose the Drying Cycle

title: Reminders & Breaks
text: 1.1 Stay still between blocks 1.2 Let you know if they need a break 1.3 Knock on the cabin wall if they need help 1.4 Look at the fixation cross when it’s on the screen.

title: Reminders & Breaks
text: 1.1 Stay still between blocks 1.2 Let you know if they need a break 1.3 Knock on the cabin wall if they need help 1.4 Look at the fixation cross when it’s on the screen.

title: Reminders & Breaks
text:
Bathroom Breaks (if needed)
Step 1: Pause recording in BrainVision






IMPORTANT



DON’T HIT THE STOP BUTTON.


Step 2: Clamp electrode bundles with clip or tie. Step 3: Walk participant to bathroom.

title: Reminders & Breaks
text:
Upon return
Step 1: Re-run impedance check to quickly ensure the electrodes are getting good readings. Step 2: Restart recording (append data). Step 3: Continue task.

title: Gel Demonstration & Impedance Setup
text:
Suggestion



If the participant has never been in an EEG experiment, it is good to demonstrate the tools you are working with and explain to them what you will be doing in order to reduce impendance.

title: Gel Demonstration & Impedance Setup
text:
Start Impedance Check
Step 1: On EEG Tower, hit Impedance button (2nd top-left in BrainVision). Electrodes will light up red.



Impedance Check on BrainVision

title: Gel Demonstration & Impedance Setup
text:
Gel Application Tips
Step 1: Angle syringe toward the electrode base. Step 2: Apply gel into each electrode until you see a small amount come out of the hole. Step 3: Swirl gel with the blunt end of the Q-tip (circular motion).









Apply Gel







Swirl with a Q-tip











IMPORTANT



Only when all electrodes are green (you have successfully reduced impendence to good level), proceed to the next step (recording).

title: Before Testing
text:
Step 1: Connect the green male wire (notch aligned) to green port on the battery.
Step 2: Do the same for the red wire and port on amplifier.






REMINDER



The battery must stay pluged in all the time when not in use.

title: Before Testing
text:
Turn on Participant Cabin Monitor
Power button is a small, hard-to-find front-bottom right button (not on back).









Power Button

title: Before Testing
section: Power on the Task Laptop and EEG Tower
text:
Power on the Task Laptop and EEG Tower
Step 1: Log into the Admin account on the EEG Tower and task laptop (password: 4073abc).
Step 2: On the Tower: Launch BrainVision Recorder (click “Yes” when prompted).
Step 3: When the program is open, you should see a gray screen.









luvadmin Account

title: Before Testing
text:
Prepare EEG Gel Syringes
The syringes are stored under the sink inside boxes.
The gel tub, tips box, Q-tips, scissors, and tissues are kept on the shelf next to the sink.









Boxes of Syringes







Gel tub, Tips box, Q-tips, Scissors & Tissues





Step 1: Take out the syringes and the tips from their packaging.
Step 2: Fill two syringes with gel.
Step 3: Close the gel tub immediately to prevent drying.
Step 4: Attach the tips to the filled syringes.
Step 5: Cut one of the Q-tips ends with the scissors.
Step 6: Place two tissues and two Q-tips on the cabin bed in preparation for the participant.









Step 1







Step 2

title: Reza Hakimazar
text: A

title: Hardware Components
text:
The EEG lab room is comprised (1) the EEG cabin (2) the workstation and (3) the cleaning station.
The task is performed inside the cabin, while the computers outside the cabin at the workstation runs the task and data collection. The workstation also includes the cleaning equipment, syringes, paper tissues, and towels.









The EEG Cabin







The Workstation







The Cleaning Station





Outside the EEG cabin, at the workstation, you find see the task laptop, the EEG tower, and the trigger box. The laptop executes the experiment task and collects behavioral data, the tower records the EEG data, and the trigger box integrates triggers with the EEG data.









EEG Tower







Battery







Trigger Box





Inside the EEG cabin, you will find the amplifier, battery, participant’s monitor, and electrode cap and cable to carry out the experiment. The electrodes are connected to the amplifier which is powered by the battery. The monitor displays the task for the participant, and the cap provides a base for the electrodes to collect the data.









Electrodes cap







Participant’s Monitor







Amplifier





The cleaning station is where you will find:









Syringes







Gel







Towels & Shampoo





Do not forget to turn on the ventilator:









Ventilator







Ventilator set on 2

title: Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
Step 1: Measure around the head like a baseball cap (~1.5 - 2 cm / ~½–1 inch above eyebrows).
Step 2: If between sizes (e.g., 57), start smaller (e.g., 56) and go up if the cap is too tight.







Available Cap Sizes:



54, 56, 58, 60











Correct Way of Head Measurement









Cap Size

title: Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
Step 1: Measure around the head like a baseball cap (~1.5 - 2 cm / ~½–1 inch above eyebrows).
Step 2: If between sizes (e.g., 57), start smaller (e.g., 56) and go up if the cap is too tight.







Available Cap Sizes:



54, 56, 58, 60











Correct Way of Head Measurement









Cap Size

title: Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
Putting on the Cap
Step 1: Ask participant to hold the back tag to help you get the cap on their head. Step 2: Pull cap on from back to front. Step 3: Ask them to keep their head up straight and steady. Step 4: Place your hand on the top of their head. Step 5: Slide the cap until it gets roughly to the right position. Step 6: Ask them to identify their occipital bone bump (back of head).









Prticipant Holding the Tag







Sliding the Cap







Occipital Bone Bump

title: Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
Check Reference Location
Step 1: Measure from the spot between eyebrows to the occipital bump.
Step 2: Measure from ear to ear. The reference electrode should be approximately midpoint between eyebrows and occipital bone as well as midpoint between the ears (ok if slightly off).
Note: This should result in the ground electrode being slightly above the eyebrows, but below the mid-forehead.
Step 3: Adjust cap again as described above if needed.










Step 1







Step 2







Checking the Reference Location

title: Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
Chin Strap
Step 1: Ask participant to fasten chin strap themselves.

title: Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
Plugging in the Electrodes
Step 1: Match Electrode Band 1–32 and 33–64 to the amplifier. Step 2: Use arrow on plug (top right) to align with amplifier port. Step 3: Insert straight in — do not bend, force, or wiggle. Step 4: Plug GND (ground electrode) separately into port labeled “GND” (round plug).









Match Electrode Bands with Amplifier







Insert Straight in









Both Bands Plugged in







Plug in the Ground

title: Starting the Recording
text:
Step 1: Hit Stop sign.
Step 2: Click the Eyeball icon.
Step 3: Hit the play button.
Step 4: Add your participants ID and other information on the file name.
Step 5: Save the file to start recording.







Check



The recording is indicated by a red bar on the bottom of the screen (“SAVING HDD”).


Step 6: Confirm that BrainVision is recording (green play button is active, time elapsed is at the bottom of the screen).

title: Starting the Recording
text:
Step 1: Hit Stop sign.
Step 2: Click the Eyeball icon.
Step 3: Hit the play button.
Step 4: Add your participants ID and other information on the file name.
Step 5: Save the file to start recording.







Check



The recording is indicated by a red bar on the bottom of the screen (“SAVING HDD”).


Step 6: Confirm that BrainVision is recording (green play button is active, time elapsed is at the bottom of the screen).

title: Starting the Recording
text: Images to be added

title: After the Task
text: Step 1: Stop BrainVision recording, by hitting the stop symbol.

title: After the Task
text: Step 1: Stop BrainVision recording, by hitting the stop symbol.

title: After the Task
text:
Cap and Electrode Removal Procedure
Step 1: Ask participant to remove chin strap.
Step 2: Remove cap by placing your fingers under the front of the cap and removing it front to back.
Step 3: Unplug the bands. (See below)






IMPORTANT



Wrap connector boxes in a towel. The connectors are very sensitive and must not be wet. Even small drops of water can damage them. Be especially careful to keep them dry.

title: After the Task
text:
Unplug Bands
Step 1: Pinch base of plug and pull straight up.







IMPORTANT



Do not pull on the wire as you may damage the connection. You should only use the plastic connector.


Step 2: For the ground electrode (labeled as GND), pinch at the plastic/amp junction and pull directly out—note that this is difficult to do so requires some force.
This CANNOT be bent or it will damage the pins inside the plug connector. DO NOT PULL ON THE WIRE.









Pinch and Pull up







Ground Electrode Unplugging

title: After the Task
text:
Post-Session Hair Cleaning Support
Step 1: Provide the time and materials for the participant to wash their hair (clean towel, shampoo, hairdryer, brush or comb). They can be found on the shelf to the left side of the cabinet under the sink.
Step 2: Close curtain for privacy



Clean towel, Shampoo, Hairdryer

title: After the Task
text:
Charge the Battery
Step 1: Move the battery from the cabin to the experimenter desk outside the cabin, plug it in by aligning the notch in the cable to the slit in the hole on the battery. Push until you hear a click.






IMPORTANT



The battery must remain plugged in to charge at all times when not in use.





Battery Plugged in


Once participant is out of EEG lab and done washing their hair proceed to the next step.

title: After the Task
text:
Electrode Cleaning
Step 1: Plug the sink and fill it with lukewarm/cold water and place them in the blue basket.






WARNING



Do not use warm water! This will damage the electrodes.


Step 2: Gently scrub gel out with a toothbrush until there is no more gel on the electrodes.
Step 3: Hang the electrodes on the hanger on the wall to the right side of the sink.






WARNING



The electrodes must not come in contact with any type of metal ever! This is very important to keep in mind at every single step of the experiment, especially while moving, washing and hanging the electrodes.


Step 4: Wash cap, hang to dry on plastic stand (left of sink). You can use the fan on the cap to dry it faster. This is necessary if you are testing more than one participant in the same day.
#IMAGES TO BE ADDED

title: BrainVision Workspace
text: Workspace saves user defined settings. It also stores all the settings you make in the amplifier and configuration menus, the impedance measurement settings. You can set up multiple workspaces with different settings, and switch between these as you wish. This provides you with an easy way to access recording parameters that you use frequently.

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
Pre-requisites

An amplifier is selected

The amplifier is connected to the recording computer

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
How to Open/Create the Workspace (Wizards)
Step 1: Click on File > New Workspace… or File > Edit Workspace…
Step 2: Data File Settings : to set all file related options

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
Amplifier Settings
The second page contains amplifier-specific parameters (1) and the channel table (2).

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
Filter Settings
There are 3 Filter Methods:

Raw Data Saving Filters
Filters are directly applied to the raw data. Use of this filter is not recommended, because this changes the raw data. When using BrainVision Analyzer you can apply filters to the raw data.
Segmentation Filters
When you specify segmentation (subsequent tab of the workspace wizard) you can also set filters for the segmented data.
Display Filters
This filter only has an effect on the display on your screen. When you set the filter, you can switch it on and off during the data display by clicking on the Display Filter button.

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
Segmentation / Averaging
This dialog allows you to make optional settings for segmentation and averaging.

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
Saving
When you click on Finish, the Save As dialog opens allowing you to save the workspace file. Give the file a meaningful name and click Save.

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
Electrode Position Files (EPF)
Used to assign electrode names, positions, and physical channels in a workspace using predefined data from the cap manufacturer. It gives users the opportunity to adapt the electrode position data (for example, the physical channel). The EPF is written in XML format and is saved as a .BVEF file. This can be opened and edited in a text editor. The file has the following structure (see also the Analyzer Manual):

title: BrainVision Workspace
text:
Create Workspace Using an EPF

Pre-requisites

An amplifier is selected

The amplifier is connected to the recording computer

Step 1: Click on File > New Workspace… or go to the Amplifier Settings dialog (second dialog page).
Step 2: Click on Use Electrode Position File.
Step 3: Select the checkbox Read positions from Electrode Position File.
Step 4: Click on Browse and locate the electrode position file (.BVEF). (If you want to check the file, click on Preview).
Step 5:* Click on Import amplifier channel table. Recorder takes over the assignment of channel names and physical channels.






Note



Don’t click this button if you edit an existing workspace and want to keep the channel assignment.


Step 6: Click on OK to load the electrode positions (topographies).
The electrode positions and the channel table (if applicable) are loaded into Recorder. The information is written into the header file. You can check the result in the impedance measurement window.






Note



Load complete files (covers the channel table and electrode topography): Steps 1–6








Note



Load electrode topography (only electrodes that are already present in the channel table): Skip Step 5
